captions.text: This volume 8 is very good !
Hey, get up !
Ho, you’re Fane, Joe Bar Team’s designer
I’m  the comic strip genius, and i’m here to make your wishes come true
Ho yeah ? Well, i would like 50 millions Euros and spend a night with Scarlett Johansson
Heu, no, it won’t be possible
But i have something else for you
Did you recognize it ?
Yes, it's Jean Raoul Ducable’s GSX-R.
In Joe Bar Team Volume 2, Jean Raoul swapped his legendary H2 for this mythical GSX-R 750.
We have here a 1992 spec,  synonym of big changes for this Japanese sport bike
because it swaps the air and oil cooling system with a liquid cooled one.
The power of the beast increases to 118 horsepower, and its top speed is now close to 270 km per hour
A boon for fighting with friends
Or ovetaking policemen…
Among other developpements of this vintage, we find more rounded lines and flashy color schemes
but the family similarities with olders GSX-R remains
thanks to the two round headlights and the traditional double-cradle frame in aluminum.
22 years later, the 750 keeps the characteristics of its age, but is still incredibly effective
A neutral and natural behavior
a very different riding position compared to modern sport bikes
because here we get the impression  to be in the bike, and not on top of it
Plus an engine that takes you quickly to unreasonable speeds!
In town, it is better to close the throttle
Because sometimes, we can meet with  this kind of funny guy
As Patrice
Compared to the garage of this crazy fellow, Ali Baba’s cavern looks like to a poor cellar
If you thought to be an ultimate fan, a Joe Bar Team extrem supporter, sorry to disappoint you
but you still have a lot of work !
Because in front of our wondering eyes appears an incredible collection
The bikes of our favorite heroes.
Including those of Volume 1, created by the famous Christian Debarre,
that tells perfectly what could be bike spirit in the 70s
It was exactly like this
One goal, be faster than our fellows
And Christian told perfectly how was the fake honesty at the bar after the ride.
I was lucky to own the Ducati, witch was one of the star of the comic trip
So it was easy for me to match with one of the hero, Guido Brasletti
How did you have the idea to collect the bikes ?
I had the idea as soon as the comics trip appears
But i thought that a lot of guys would have the same idea so i didn’t do it
Then i saw that no one did it. And i still have the Ducati, which is the most difficult bike to find.
And i never had an English bike, si why not a Norton
It Began like this. So i bought the other bikes : H2 later, the CB 750…
Look at these jewels !
And look how Patrice reproduced all the details, to be as close as possible to the comic's bikes.
Guido’s Ducati 900 SS
with its 3 brake discs, its big carbs, its Conti exhausts and cones without air filter
Manchzeck’s Norton Commando, a perfect example of British jewelery.
Enjoy the racing looks, enhanced by the addition of clip-ons
What did the H2 represent ?
It was the bomb. The most racing one.
In 750 Production category, all the other bikes disappeared
It became a single brand cup, a Kawasaki H2 cup.
And, comparing to the stock bike, what did Jeannot La Case change ?
There are not a lot of differences. It’s an H2 B, with clip-ons.
I put some flashing lights, wich are not in the comic strip.
We just have to start it and let’s go ?
Ok, no problem.
From the beginning of Joe Bar Team, Jeannot La Case  was accustomed to very sporty machines
A sign of his desires to be a top rider.
This is also the only one who tried to go beyond the status of neighborhood champion,
to  take the start of a real hill climb race.
A race that will end memorably
Released by Kawasaki in 1972, the H2 will quickly dominates club races
Must say that its big 750 engine still breathes fire.
When you open the throttle, the RPM needle rushes tskywards in typical two-stroke engine's scream
ter 6000 RPM, the three cylinder gets very angry.
But more than the power, the vibrations are the most hallucinating thing.
40 years ago, how the hell did they manage to ride this vibrator
which makes your hands and forearms numb after only 10 minutes time !
As for the gearbox,  neutral gear is down below the other ones
and you can easily  fall on it when you shift down quickly
right in time to enter a turn
Add to this the chronical inefficiency of the brakes
and you're ready for some great moments of loneliness !
What a trap !! I do not want to die! Hop, return to sender!
So, how was the ride ?
It was great ! Can i ask your another wish ?
What ?
Can you show me how do you work ?
Ok, it’s your dream.
Ho thanks !
In 1990, the first volume of Joe Bar Team comics was released
Drawn by the great Christian Debarre, who was Moto Journal' illustrator at the time.
In 1993, Stéphane Déteindre, better known as Fane, would take over and produce volumes 2, 3, 4, 6
and more recently, Volume 8, where Pierrot, Jeremy and Paulo are to be found.
The three characters that he imagined to enlarge the JBT troupe.
I made my casting and i created this three fellows
Who were inspirated by me and some of my friends
but they quickly get their independance and became real characters.
I needed to put some of my own experience in the comics
and not only continue the aventure with Christian’s characters
Because i was a young rider, and to be able to borrow anecdotes in my own life,
i had to put the Joe Bar Team in the 90’s
That’s why these three characters are born.
Paulo had always been my favorite one. Because, in a certain way, it’s me
And you see, he’s on my XT 500
When i draw this, i thing about me saying « drum brakes are really shit ! »
In the Joe Bar Team, each rider and his bike form a real couple, a real comedy duo.
And if motorcycle is well adapted to picture or video, it’s the same for comic strip
t’s dynamic, dishevel… it’s alive
In a humorous comic, bike is awesome because you can twirl it as a character
You can play with suspensions, with the wheels, the tires can be distorted.
You can make the bike speak. Make it humain, alive.
Ok, bike drawings are a good thing. But a bike, it’s better when you ride it, isn’t it ?
Well, yes
I have a last surprise for you. It’s outside.
Ouha, Pierrot Lafouine’s Vmax 1700.
Fan is definetely a good genius
Straight after having passed his driving license, Pierre Legnôme chose the Yamaha Vmax 1200.
Dispite a slighlty out of control riding style thanks to the V4 hosepower
La Fouine did not hesitate in Volume 7 to move to the next level
and couldn’t resist to the unreasonable Vmax 1700 !
Given the little size of the man, we easy understand that he struggled to manage this fierce monster!
The Vmax is one of the craziest creatures ever produced  by a Japanese brand.
At first, the muscular looks and dragster style, give informations about the dynamic capabilities of the bike.
And then there is the massive 200 horsepower V4, built like a cathedral
The limousine wheelbase : 1700 mm long.
Or the huge rear tyre, which willingly smoke like a chimney ...
At the start line of a quartermile race, it's clear that you're the boss
However, as soon as the road becomes twisty you have to manage the 310 kg of the machine
Especially when the asphat is wet, as it was during this test.
Then, you have to ride the Yamaha with modesty, knowing that any twist of the wrist may cause long sides
And a too optimisc braking will be responsible for a few liters of cold sweats ...
To complete our exploration of the JBT world, we simply returned to the office.
Because at the end of the 80s
many tales of Moto Journal's test riders  gave birth to some of the Joe Bar Team first volume's most colorfull pages
It comes from here
We were happy to work together, to go all together in test rides.
This one was one of the most exiting comparative we made
It was the 600cc class GP comparative.
When you saw the first Joe Bar Team volume, did you recognize real anecdotes ?
Yes, off course. There’s a true sentence, i said it after a very hot test ride
I stopped and i said « faster would be dangerous, faster wouldn't be reasonable »
Joe Bar Team spirit is born in Moto Journal, during the riding tests
Above all, we were really happy to ride together.
As in the good old days, Moto Journal comparative tests still create proper fights
complete with bluff and fake honesty.
Test riders or simple bikers alike, generations passes, but the spirit remains.
And the timeless success of Joe Bar Team comics surely from there ?
So, did you like your dream ?
It was so great. I rode Joe Bar Team’s bikes, i saw a very nice collection, i saw you working…
It’s wonderful, i’m so happy
Ok, good. Now  you can piss off
Well, no thanks. I’m fine
Fans are nices but sometimes, some of them pain in this ass
Shut up, i’m sleeping !

title: ESSAI JOE BAR TEAM : On a taxé les motos de la BD ! (English Subtitles)
